title: VIRSTA Score for Infective Endocarditis Risk Assessment
description: The VIRSTA Score is a clinical decision tool used to risk-stratify suspected infective endocarditis cases before obtaining echocardiography. This score helps identify patients at very low risk for infective endocarditis who may not require immediate echocardiographic evaluation, thereby reducing unnecessary testing and healthcare costs while maintaining diagnostic safety.

parameters.name: valve_disease_or_prosthetic_valve
parameters.description: Presence of known valve disease (including rheumatic heart disease, congenital valve disease, or degenerative valve disease) or prosthetic valve

parameters.name: injection_drug_use
parameters.description: History of injection drug use (current or past)

parameters.name: vascular_phenomena
parameters.description: Presence of vascular phenomena including major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, or Janeway lesions

parameters.name: immunologic_phenomena
parameters.description: Presence of immunologic phenomena including glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, or rheumatoid factor

parameters.name: systemic_emboli
parameters.description: Evidence of systemic arterial emboli (excluding those included in vascular phenomena)

parameters.name: wbc_over_11000
parameters.description: White blood cell count greater than 11,000/μL (11.0 × 10⁹/L)

parameters.name: central_venous_catheter
parameters.description: Presence of central venous catheter or other intravascular device

result.name: virsta_score
result.description: VIRSTA score for infective endocarditis risk assessment

ranges.description: Very low probability of infective endocarditis
ranges.interpretation: VIRSTA score 0-1 indicates very low risk for infective endocarditis (negative predictive value >99%). Echocardiography may be deferred in these patients unless clinical suspicion remains high based on other factors. Consider alternative diagnoses and outpatient management with close follow-up.

VIRSTA score ≥2 indicates increased risk for infective endocarditis. Echocardiography is recommended for further evaluation. Consider transesophageal echocardiography if transthoracic echocardiography is negative and clinical suspicion remains high. Initiate appropriate antimicrobial therapy and monitor for complications.

references: Sunnerhagen T, Törnell A, Vikbrant M, et al. VIRSTA score: prediction of infective endocarditis and mortality in Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia; a cohort study. Clin Microbiol Infect. 2019;25(4):480-486. doi: 10.1016/j.cmi.2018.06.021

Palraj BR, Baddour LM, Hess EP, et al. Predicting risk of endocarditis using a clinical tool (PREDICT): scoring system to guide use of echocardiography in the setting of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. Clin Infect Dis. 2015;61(1):18-28. doi: 10.1093/cid/civ235

Bouza E, Kestler M, Beca T, et al. The NOVA score: a proposal to reduce the need for transesophageal echocardiography in patients with enterococcal bacteremia. Clin Infect Dis. 2015;60(4):528-535. doi: 10.1093/cid/ciu872
formula: Sum of positive criteria: Valve disease/prosthetic valve (5 points) + Injection drug use (5 points) + Vascular phenomena (4 points) + Immunologic phenomena (3 points) + Systemic emboli (3 points) + Temperature >38°C (2 points) + Age >60 years (2 points) + WBC >11,000/μL (1 point) + Central venous catheter (1 point) + Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia (1 point)
notes: Originally developed and validated in patients with Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia
Score ≤1 has negative predictive value >99% for ruling out infective endocarditis
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and not as sole determinant
Particularly useful in emergency department and inpatient settings for triaging patients
May help reduce unnecessary echocardiographic studies while maintaining diagnostic safety
Validation studies have shown good discrimination ability (AUC 0.87-0.89)
Best performance when applied to patients with confirmed bacteremia and clinical suspicion of endocarditis
